dialogues.speaker: CASTLE
dialogues.text: Now comes the moon riding over the horizon. Upon a hill a the edge of the wood squats a castle, its crude stonework bathed in cold silvery light. Queer carvings and runes decorate the ponderous gate. Heavy vines are climbing up walls. The castle is old, its unfamiliar form testament t an ancient mind and an ancient craft. Flickering candle l dances ona leaded windowpane. Inside, the corridors are dark and silent. Under low arch ceilings the uneven floors are paved with stone blocks. Perched over lintels and crouched in niches are icons wit strange animal heads.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Asleep ona straw palette in a room strewn with vegetables and crockery is Hodge, a wrinkled old retainer. A flicker candle and empty jug are beside the bed. He is snoring ge

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: This circular chamber at the heart of the castle is stuff with parchments, scrolls, dusty books, bronze braziers, g retorts, chemical salts, birds both stuffed and caged. An iron candelabra stands on a work table, tapers burning. I the soft glow it seems that the room is unoccupied, but n moving in the background is a shadowy figure, preparing f a magical deed. Feet are positioned carefully within a pentagram chiseled into the floor. A scroll is consulted; comes an arm and a voice blurts out: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omnia in duos: Duo in Unum: Unus in Nihil: Haec nec Quattuor nec Omnia nec Duo nec Unus nec Nihil Sunt. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Come on, candles, out! But the little flames stand at attention without so much a tremble.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: In Volunta Divina et Verbum Magi: Lux! Exstinguat! It's no use. There is a sigh and the figure moves forward into the light. Revealed in the glow is the discouraged f of Galen Bradwardyn, sorcerer's apprentice.

dialogues.speaker: TOWER
dialogues.text: Carrying the candelabra, the youth trudges up a circular staircase.

dialogues.speaker: TURRET
dialogues.text: The highest point of the castle is a turret, open to the stars and the night air. Here, more magic is afoot. An ol enchanter, Ulrich, Magister Ipsissimus, pours water from silver ewer into a stone bowl. As the surface ripples disappear he leans forward and gazes into the pool. All a once his face hardens as the distant sounds of screams an thunder reach his ears. Lights and shadows, reflected fro within the basin, play across his face. His frown deepens the sound of his own voice comes to him from the vision i the water вЂ” Draco draconis вЂ” suddenly squelched by th roar of flame and an ugly snarl. At that moment Galen reaches the top of the steps and hol up the candelabra.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Vide, Magister. There's something Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  wrong. Ulrich, startled from his trance, slaps the water out of basin and turns to confront his student. Galen is taken a by the old man's grim countenance.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: What's the matter? What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: I've just seen something. Something of consequence to you.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: To me?

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (calm) Yes. My own death. With a distracted gesture he causes the flames to extingu themselves.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Perhaps we had better hasten your training.

dialogues.speaker: BARNYARD
dialogues.text: Outside the castle wall Hodge is feeding the chickens and ducks. He straightens up and squints through the early mo mists. On a distant hillock two figures are moving toward the woods.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH AND GALEN
dialogues.text: Hobbling slowly with the aid of a pair of canes, Ulrich g his pupil across a wooden bridge and along a stream into forest.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (stern and troubled) This wood, these leaves, the birds, Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  the very dome of heaven, once they all rang with one great chord: and philosophers like me kept it all in tune. Now, new voices are singing new songs. (sharply) Have you mastered the threefold transmutation?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (skeptical) You have?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Well, almost.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: It's very difficult. Have you committed to memory undying the Codex de Profundis?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (a shrug) The first two chapters.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: It's long. And what about the Ritual of Banishment as prescribed by my late master Balisarius?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: To tell the truth, | haven't dared try it. What's the point, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: The point? The point is you don't know it, and you're no magician without it. It was my hope to school you, to mold your faculties and wits... | still believe you have some talent. Somewhere. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | hate books. | hate drill. |want a real task.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: There's no time now. When I'm gone, half the powers in the universe will vanish with me. And what's the use of a few lingering skills if they're left in the hands of a child? (pause) Listen!

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: | don't hear anything. Ulrich gauges the young man standing before him and makes decision. Reaching under his cloak he lifts off a fine si chain with an amulet dangling from it. He drapes it aroun Galen's neck.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Here, wear this. Galen instinctively wraps his hand around the jewel. He c an ear.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Voices, singing on the road. He hastens forward to a promontory, eager to have a look. Ulrich does not follow. Instead, doffing his cloak, he wh it before him, where it magically floats a few feet off t ground. Awkwardly, the old man clambers aboard.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: | don't see anything. He turns back, but the wizard is gone. A shadow falls ove him. He looks up. There, two hundred feet above the tree tops his master is soaring on the wind.

dialogues.speaker: AIRBORNE
dialogues.text: The old conjurer squints into the distance. Miles away an Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca far below a company of drab walkers winds along the marg of the forest. They are singing a mournful round.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: He gawks skyward. Suddenly, the old man leans down and addresses him.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (a shout) We have visitors!

dialogues.speaker: ROTUNDA
dialogues.text: Clustering together in the center of a wide reception hal is a contingent of weary peasants, awkward amidst the dus rugs, drapes and heavy furniture. Their leader is a fineb youth, not yet twenty. Like the others, he is uneasy; his name is Valerian. Hodge enters and sets a tray of mead be them. He leaves without a word. The visitors stare glumly the refreshment, but are too timorous to go near it.

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen helps Ulrich prepare for the audience. The sorcerer peers at himself in a full4ength mirror, adjusting the he of a black robe.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Looks forbidding enough, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Here are your sticks.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: No вЂ” they'll think me infirm. You know, Balisarius wore this whenever he changed lead into gold. He could really do that, you know. | never could. Too bad вЂ” you'd stand to inherit some real wealth. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a morbid frame of mind. What's all this about dying? You don't even look sick.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (tying on a sash) You still wearing that amulet? (Galen nods) Good. Don't lose it. It still belongs to me. He backs away from the mirror and fits a silver coronet o his head.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Now, adeptus minor, get yourself a handful of that sulphurous ash over there... The sorcerer starts down a circular stone staircase.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROTUNDA
dialogues.text: The visitors watch warily as a door swings open and Galen makes his entrance, his face expressionless and hands pre together. He looks rather young to be the famous Ulrich. Galen allows a moment to go by, then throws his arms wide Ka-whump! and Ulrich appears in the doorway in a smoky fireball. Alarmed, the visitors retreat.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Nunc habeus lux! Pffst! around the room candles flare in their niches.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Et calor! In the fireplace, the birch logs are suddenly ablaze. Ulr totters to the hearth and extends long bony fingers towar the warmth.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Welcome to Cragganmore. | am Ulrich. Which one of you calls himself Valerian? The travelers are suitably dazzled by the magician's performance. The young leader of the party screws up his courage and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: That would be me. We are here on behalf...

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: | know why you're here. You're a delegation from Urland, from beyond Dalvatia. Let's see the artifacts. The travelers exchange nervous glances. Valerian motions one of his companions. The man steps forward and hands ov a leather pouch. One by one, Valerian places the contents the table for Ulrich's inspection.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: A bone. Scorched. A rock, fire- blackened. (pause) Scales. At this, Ulrich advances and closely examines three shimm irridescent disks as big as saucers.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: All right. How did you come by these?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: (proudly) | found them. At the mouth of the lair.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (grim) What else? Valerian reaches under his jerkin and withdraws what appe to be a curved sword. He jabs it into the table. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A claw.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: That's no claw. It's a tooth. By the gods! He runs a finger along a serrated edge and gazes bleakly his visitors.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: And you want me to do battle with that? Valerian has lost all trace of timidity.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Who else can we turn to? We all know what we're dealing with here. This is a basilicok. (he takes a step forward) A cockatrice. (another step, bolder) A dragon. (he leans close to Ulrich) This is no stag, no bear, no natural creature. This is one of your kind. And only a necromancer such as yourself can rid us of it.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Did you try the Meredydd sisters? What about Rinbod? I've heard it said he killed a dragon once.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: They're all dead. You're the only one left. With a sigh, Ulrich lowers himself into a chair. He rubs withered legs and shakes his head. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long way to Urland.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Every quarter, upon the solstices and the equinoxes there's a new victim. Greil, a grizzled peasant, speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: My daughter, for one.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER TRAVELERS
dialogues.text: My sister... cousins...

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: All women?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Girls. Virgins, to be exact, chosen by lot. Galen edges over to the table and inspects the scales and tooth.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Master, don't you think вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Silence! He broods for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Are you afraid of dragons?

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: No. Sorcerers and dragons go backa long long time together. If it weren't for sorcerers, there wouldn't be any dragons. (pause) All right. I'll go. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: The travelers are making ready for departure in the grey light of dawn. As Hodge stuffs provisions into a wicker b Ulrich wraps padding on a newly fashioned pair of crutche

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: | know of this dragon. Vermithrax Pejorative: she's four hundred years old. As far as | can tell she's the last of her kind. Very appropriate that I'm the one to finish her off, don't you think? (he tries out the crutches) There. Flatten the highest mountain. What say you, Galen? (no answer) Speak up. (still no answer) You, Hodge. Hodge mutters something inaudible and grimly keeps packin

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (to Galen) While I'm gone see you keep your nose in your books and your hands out of my reagents. Leave my instruments alone too. Galen crouches against the castle wall; he regards his ma sullenly.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Look at yourself. How far will you get like that? A league, two leagues?

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about the road.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Why don't you wave your hands around and summon up a coach-and-four?

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Don't mock me. Galen gets up and calls out to the Urlanders.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: You pilgrims: You're used to lotteries. Why not draw straws to see who'll be first to carry ironshanks here. This is too much for Hodge.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Hold your tongue. If the master's got a mind to go, he'll go. Galen approaches the old sorcerer.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Send me. You're always saying | need seasoning. | need a test. Let me go.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: You're not ready.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: I'm ready for anything.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (wan smile) Don't be so hasty. Your time will come. The walkers are ready to set forth. Hodge picks up his pa steps forward and pulls open the great gate.

dialogues.speaker: HORSEMEN
dialogues.text: Three mounted men are outside the gate, helmets on their heads, swords on the belts and longbows across their shoulders. They look formidable. The Urlanders take a ste Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  backward.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Tyrian!? Tyrian is a lean, heavily bearded nobleman. There is a co of arms on the shield strapped to the pommel of his saddl

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: (amiable) Good morning, all.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: We're not afraid of you. Give us the road.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Why, the road is yours. All the way to Urland. It's a long journey, isn't it? But when you're in search of a sorcerer, | suppose no distance is too great. Sensing trouble, Galen moves forward. Ulrich touches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Say nothing. Galen hears the urgency in the old man's voice and obeys. Hodge takes it upon himself to deal with the strangers.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: What do you want with us?

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Well, like my good friends here, I've come for a bit of black magic. No doubt you've heard of our troubles at home. This is Cragganmore, is it not?

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Aye, this be the place of Ulrich. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Tyrian dismounts and saunters up to the old magician.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: And here we have the mystical presence himself, no?

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: You'd best keep your distance вЂ” and your manners.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: If he's ready to lay a dragon in its grave, he's got nothing to fear from me. (turns to the Urlanders) I've no more love for that creature than you lot. Nor has the King. But, before you stir things up, don't you think ita good idea to see you've got the right man for the job?

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Aha - it's a test you're looking for. We don't do tests.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: I'm sure you don't. They never do tests - and not many real deeds either. Oh, conversation with your grandmother's shade in a darkened room, the odd love potion or two... but comes a doubter, well then, it's the wrong day, the planets are not aligned, the entrails aren't favorable, we don't do tests.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: We've got no doubts. We require no test.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: And you're not going to get one. When Ulrich finally speaks, his voice is low and Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  authoritative.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: (to Galen) Go to the conjuring room. The iron box. Fetch me the dagger within. Galen's eyes widen with alarm.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: The dagger. Be quick. Galen dashes into the castle. Ulrich gazes almost shyly a Tyrian.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: You shall have your test.

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen comes puffing up the steps, locates the iron box, a flings it open. Amidst the tawdry paraphernalia of a professional magician is an ivory-handled dagger covered with runic inscriptions. Galen eagerly examines it to see how the blade might twist aside or collapse into the hand but it is all too genuine. A murder weapon.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (impatient) Where are you, boy? I'm waiting. Galen throws open a window and looks down into the courty He displays the dagger.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Not this one, was it?

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: The very one. Let it fall. Galen hesitates, then tosses it. Tumbling end over end, i arcs downward. The old conjurer calmly stretches out a ha and plucks it neatly out of the air. Galen watches as Ulr passes the weapon to Tyrian and strips back his robe expo a bony chest. Galen knows what's coming. He rushes for th Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca door. He's only a step away when it bangs shut of its ow accord. He sprints for a second exit. Whack! This door sl shut too. Locked in. Quick, back to the window and climb down the vine... Smack! the heavy shutters seal him in.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH AND TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Ulrich takes Tyrian's arm and guides the point of the dag to his breastbone.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Vita regula, vita hieratica! Everyone is filled with dread. Hodge is shaking. From the castle come the rattling of shutters and Galen's muffled cries. A sick sarcastic smile has crept over Tyrian's lip He tenses himself to thrust.

dialogues.speaker: ULRICH
dialogues.text: Go on. Don't worry, you can't hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen stops hammering and presses his face to a crack in shutter. Below he can see the participants in this grisly drama. He holds his breath. Tyrian makes a sudden movemen and buries the blade in Ulrich's chest. But the sorcerer stands unbent, seemingly unhurt. Then, after a long momen he slowly sags forward over the dagger and the hand that holds it. Tyrian shrinks back and allows the body to fall a heap. Very quickly he remounts. In another moment he an his companions are gone. The others are riveted in horror Hodge sinks to his knees and wails his grief. Galen turns away from the window and gazes blankly into t gloomy conjuring room. Click! The doors unlatch themselve and swing open.

dialogues.speaker: FUNERAL PYRE
dialogues.text: Ulrich, principal magician and sorcerer of the western wo reposes ona hardwood pyre. His hands are folded on his ch Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca His face is peaceful. While the visitors wordlessly look Galen touches a burning brand to the kindling. At first t fire catches normally enough, but when the flames start t envelop the body they suddenly turn pale green, producing unearthly roar. The onlookers back away from the intense heat.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: The erstwhile apprentice stands his ground, blinking back tears, his face weirdly illuminated by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: CONJURING ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen sits alone amidst the museum4ike collection of magi apparatus. He stares at the amulet, considering its significance. His reverie is interrupted by the murmur of voices below. At the window he looks down to see Hodge bi farewell to the delegation from Urland. Valerian is the l to leave. He pauses at the gate and glances up at Galen. Then he moves on. The young student of magic sets his jaw suddenly filled with resolve. Moving through the room, he busies himself with the old m effects. He scoops up the loose books and parchments and locks them into trunks. He drapes muslin cloths over the alchemical devices. He sows a handful of salt over the pentagram inscribed in the floor. Finally, he opens the c and releases the crow, the falcon, and the great horned o

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Hodge is up on the burned out funeral pyre, anxiously scr ashes and small bones into a leather pouch вЂ” the remain Ulrich. Up behind him comes Galen, now clad in a traveler cloak, with a pack on his back and a staff in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Hodge вЂ” what are you doing? Hodge quickly conceals the pouch.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Just making my farewell, thank you very much. He quickly climbs down, picks up his pack and follows Gal out through the gate. As the door is pushed shut a huge o timber falls into place, barring the castle against the uninvited.

dialogues.speaker: HILLTOP
dialogues.text: Galen and Hodge labor to the crest of a grassy hill and t to look back across a wide valley. There on another hillt on the far side sits Cragganmore, lit by the red rays of setting sun. Galen removes the amulet from his neck and clutches it in his fist. Hodge is bug-eyed to see it.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Be careful with that! You don't know what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Stand back! He raises his hands toward the castle and calls out:

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Cragganmore! Domus noni am! Silva celet!

dialogues.speaker: CRAGGANMORE
dialogues.text: The vines on the castle walls begin to twitch and stretch magically brought to animate life. They flow upward over masonry, branching out and covering every surface, then u onto the roof. Finally only the tops of the chimneys and highest turrets stand above the green carpet. A century's growth in a matter of seconds.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: On their hilltop the old retainer gives the youth a fearf look. Galen is too flushed with excitement over what he h done to notice. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: FOREST PATH
dialogues.text: Galen and Hodge trudge along an overgrown cart-track unde an arch of trees.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a vale of tears in which we dwell. It doesn't matter who you are, a king in his robes, a peasant in his rags, when your time comes, no magic can save you...

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: I guess... The apprentice's mind is elsewhere: he's got a coin hover in mid-air above his palm, bobbing gently as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: ..the kindest lord a man could ask for... now he's gone. Ye gods he was fussy about his bath. And you'd think he could boil his own eggs with the snap of a finger, but no, he had old Hodge do it, of course. (snurfling) Up before five | was, mucking out the cages, slopping the pigs, and never once got so much as a thankyou or a pat on the back... (through tears) I'm going to miss him.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Me too... He plucks a low-hanging leaf, waves a hand over it, and watches it turn into a spray of daffodils.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: No you don't. All you care about is the tricks and knavery. Well, you Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  don't pull any wool over these old eyes. It'll be a mighty long walk before you fill his shoes, you mark my word.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Hodge, pack too heavy? Here. He gives the pack a slap. It flies out of its harness and floats alongside them. Hodge snatches it back and clutche it tightly.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Careful with that!

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Too cold, is it? A great coat drapes itself over Hodge's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Too warm? The greatcoat disappears, as do the rest of his garments, leaving him in his smalls.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: (spluttering) Stop it, |say! Out of respect for the master! Suppressing a grin, Galen mercifully waves his hand and restores Hodge to his usual costume.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: I've got as much respect for the master as anyone, old man. But вЂ” then again, I'm master now.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Urlanders are gathered around a fire, sharing a meage supper. The man named Greil pokes at the stew-pot.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: I left my farm with seeds unplanted, calves unborn, nothing but a wife to chase down the strays, and for what? A funeral, that's what. He walks up and down behind Valerian.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Because some people said, find a magician. Not just a local fellow, an import, a good forty leagues from home. An all-powerful necromancer. Ha вЂ”some necromancer! Malkin, an older man, speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: MALKIN
dialogues.text: Hold your tongue, Greil. Sit. Eat.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: I'll not sit. I'll not eat. See you the Great Bear. His tail points east. It's the equinox. Have you forgotten? Or rather not think about it?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: (miserable) He's right. | brought us here for nothing. May the gods help whoever's daughter it is tonight. There is a noise from the darkness beyond the campfire. T of the men get to their feet and listen. At first silence then more rustling. Without a word the two men dart into bushes and haul two interlopers before the company: Galen and Hodge.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Good morrow, good morrow. Peace be Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  with you.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Easy now. We mean no harm. We've been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: (growl) Well, you've found us.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (brushing himself off) More the other way around, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: A few words, that's all. You were looking for a conjurer.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Right. Requiscat in pace. (he takes a deep breath) Ecce: magister novus!

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: How say you? Galen surveys the puzzled faces. He draws himself up and plunges in:

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: My lord Ulrich is no longer. All that you asked of him, you may now expect of me. The dangers he would face, | will now conquer. The task he would undertake | will now fulfill. lam Galen Bradwardyn, inheritor of Ulrich's craft and knowledge, and | am the Sorcerer you seek. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca There is a moment of depressed silence. Hodge rolls his Greil starts to chuckle, then to laugh. Soon the others a laughing too.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Well, that's a handsome thought, O wizard of wizards. But if there's one thing our friend Tyrian has shown us, it's to beware the pig in the poke. Who's got a dagger?

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: No tests!!

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Call it proof, then. Someone brings out a dagger and hands it to Greil. Valeri pushes it away.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: We've seen enough tests. But Greil persists, waving the knife at the group.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Well | haven't. All I've seen is death. Death in our families, death on the road, and tonight, death at home. He lashes out with the knife. Galen jumps back, but Valer steps in, delivering a quick kick to Greil's gut, followe by a right to the jaw that sends the bigger man sprawling He takes the knife.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: What's come over you, anyway? Have you lost your wits? He propels Galen out of harm's way and sits him down on t other side of the fire. Greil nurses his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: | don't like it. Young snot-nose Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  comes in here for sport at our expense. We're on a fool's errand, but we don't have to listen to this. | don't want to hear any more about sorcery. | don't want to hear any more about spells. Valerian hands Galen a plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: You must be hungry.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (nods) What's the matter with him?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: It's not just him. It's all of us. It's the equinox. They both look up at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: The moon shines down on the far reaches of the Kingdom of Urland, coldly lighting a barren landscape filled with th skeletons of dead trees, blackened rock and bare ground. Advancing across this mournful terrain is a troop of arme men leading a blindfolded horse and tumbril. The horse is skittish. Finally, in spite of shouts and lashings, it re to go further. The leader, Horsrik, barks out an order:

dialogues.speaker: HORSRIK
dialogues.text: Close enough! Bring her out! A young woman, no more than seventeen, is brought forth f the cart. Long black hair falls down over a white tunic. dark eyes dart fearfully around in her pale face. She is half-carried, half dragged to the edge of a steaming crac in the ground where she is manacled to a wooden post. By lantern4ight, Horsrik reads from a parchment scroll.

dialogues.speaker: HORSRIK
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Now be it known throughout the kingdom, that this maiden, having lawfully been chosen by a deed of fortune and destiny, shall hereby give up her life for the greater good of Urland. There is a low rumble; the earth shakes. Horsrik glances nervously around. He carries on by rote.

dialogues.speaker: HORSRIK
dialogues.text: By this act shall be satisfied the powers that dwell underground and the spirits that attend thereto. In gratitude for this sacrifice His Majesty has declared the family вЂ” what's the name? вЂ” He prods the girl, but she is too terrified to speak. Ben them, the earth seems to groan. Smoke issues from the mou of the pit. One of the nervous witnesses leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: RETAINER
dialogues.text: Plowman! The family Plowman!

dialogues.speaker: HORSRIK
dialogues.text: (rushing it) вЂ” the family Plowman to be free of obligations, taxations, levys and imposts for a period not to exceed five years... The horse suddenly rears, and blindfold notwithstanding, gallops off, dragging the tumbril over the rocks. The men behind Horsrik break ranks and scatter.

dialogues.speaker: HORSRIK
dialogues.text: вЂ” ordained and signed this day, etc., Casiodorus, in his glory the reigning king of this our realm... his seal, his mark, duly read by Chancellor Horsrik in his holy name. Now Horsrik joins the flight, chasing his men back over t murky horizon. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strains against her manacles, cocking her head to lis as the rumblings below subside. Presently the steam and s blow away and she can see the horse pawing and stamping a hundred yards distant, the wheel of the cart jammed betwe rocks. Summoning up a wild will to live, she squeezes her hands against the cold iron rings. No use. She spits on h wrists and twists desperately. Blood starts. One hand sli free. She looks at the horse. The animal tosses off its blindfold and looks back at her. Now she strains again an pulls her other hand free. She wipes the blood on her fro and sprints toward the horse. But she doesn't get there. earth abruptly shifts from under her feet, tumbling her a cracked and steaming rocks. When she raises her head a hu shadow has fallen over the horse. There is a piteous whin then a roar. The girl's face is suddenly lit by flames. S scrambles to her feet and rushes back the other way.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHASE
dialogues.text: The girl hasn't taken a dozen steps when something huge hurtles forward and blocks her way. Something scaly and glittering. She whirls and stumbles off in a new directio This time she's cut off by a monstrous claw tipped with r like talons. She screams and crawls away. Another claw prevents her escape.

dialogues.speaker: THE CREATURE
dialogues.text: Membranous wings fold down against the night sky. Up come the silhouette of a reptilian head swaying on a serpentin neck. There's an angry hiss. A sheet of flame envelops everything.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST
dialogues.text: Tyrian kneels beside a mountain waterfall, having a drink while his men hover in the background. One of them points down the slope. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. | see them. Tyrian wipes his mouth unhurriedly and strolls over to lo Far below, half hidden by trees, the little company of Urlanders winds its way through the forest. A frown creeps over Tyrian's face.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Who's that old man?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Where? Which one?

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: That one. That's the man from Cragganmore. Now what's he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Filling in for the chief, | reckon.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: (weary) What a pity.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Hodge marches along with the rest. When he's sure no one else is looking he burrows into his garments and brings o the leather pouch containing Ulrich's ashes. Reassured th it's still with him, he tucks it away again. Galen falls into step.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: What have you got there?

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  A little gold, eh? What do you say | change it into lead?

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Save your jokes for someone else. Me, | don't care for braggarts. They pass Valerian, who has dropped out of line.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: And | don't care for frauds.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: I'm no fraud.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Call it fool then. Upstart. Whatever pleases you.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Hodge, nobody forced you to come along.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm here of my own free will, all right. We each do the master's bidding in our own way.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Well, if he told you | needed wetnursing, why don't you just turn yourself around and go back home. Hodge snorts and fusses with his pack.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Home, is it? You've seen to that, haven't you? Gone to seed, I'd say... He glances over and discovers Galen missing.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: He walks back along the trail, looking for Valerian. Pret soon the rest of the travelers are out of sight. He hears Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  the sound of a splash. He turns off the trail and pushes through some shrubbery.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST POOL
dialogues.text: Under the oaks and hickory, a forest stream has widened i a quiet pool. A pile of clothes lies on a rock at the edg Out in the middle, Valerian is treading water.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: You're too far behind us. Come on out.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: You go ahead, I'll catch up.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Not a good idea to get separated. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Right. I'll be along. Galen leans over and splashes some water on his face. Fee good. He shucks his pack and starts to throw off his clot Valerian doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: That's all right. Don't come in. But Galen is now naked and walking into the water. He swi out toward Valerian.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: (edgy) You better get back to the group, they're probably worried. Galen keeps swimming.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: | prefer to swim alone, if you don't mind. But Galen has slipped beneath the surface; he doesn't hea Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galen works his way through the murky green underwater wo Suddenly, he stops short and stares. He's only a few feet from Valerian's dangling legs. He gasps in surprise. Vale is no boy.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE
dialogues.text: Galen comes shooting to the surface, coughing and sputter

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: By the gods! Valerian is pale and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Stay away. She propels herself backward, then turns and swims for sh

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SHORE
dialogues.text: Galen and Valerian have taken refuge behind separate bush Briskly they pull on their clothes.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: I suppose you'll tell everyone. Go ahead, | don't care. It's a relief.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: I'm not going to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: | don't blame you. | was stupid. Careless. A silly woman!

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (feeble bluff) Take it easy. | knew the moment | saw you. I've known the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: You never knew a thing. No one knew. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Not since | was born. Go on, run off and tell them. It'll make a great story.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Don't worry. No one's going to find out. Just tell me: why?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Ask my father. They finish dressing in silence. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: The lottery! Daughters are chosen, but sons are not!

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: That's right. Unless you have plenty of gold or property.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: If you're rich enough, your name never goes in. (bitter) My father is poor. So are a lot of fathers. He studies her. She jams a hat down over her head and, on more the young man, stalks off.

dialogues.speaker: THE VISION
dialogues.text: Galen walks down to the edge of the pool to retrieve his pack. As he leans over he catches sight of what appears t be a reflection in the water: Tyrian on horseback. He whi around, but no one is behind him. Riveted by the vision, hurries along the bank to follow it. After a few paces th blurry figure dismounts, unslings a longbow, nocks an arr and draws the string taut.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  (horrified) No!

dialogues.speaker: FOREST
dialogues.text: Galen sprints through the trees. Up ahead is Valerian, wa resolutely.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: No! She glances back at him and grimly keeps on walking. Gale shoots past her and on into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Hodge!

dialogues.speaker: TRAVELERS
dialogues.text: Galen races up the trail rounds a bend and sees the Urlan coming toward him. Hodge precedes the group with an unste gait. He sees Galen, raises up his arms and flops face do on the trail. A long arrow protrudes from his back. Galen kneels beside him. The uneasy company keeps its distance. Hodge struggles to speak.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Galen? Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: | hear you.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: You know, somebody shot me, but | can still talk. There's something that has to be done.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: | know.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Not that cockatrice. Ulrich's ashes. Here. Hodge's hand comes out from under his coat gripping the Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  leather pouch. Galen tugs at it, but Hodge can't let go.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: Take it. Sorry, you'll have to peel it loose. Galen pries the sack out of Hodge's clenched fingers. Sud the hand comes up, grabs Galen by the hair, and pulls him near.

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: (a croak) ..burning water... find the lake, throw it in...

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (holding up the pouch) What are you doing with this, Hodge?

dialogues.speaker: HODGE
dialogues.text: ..burning water... He dies. Galen frees himself from his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Hodge, don't die. Listen to me. You're not going to die. Galen is frantic. He pulls out the amulet and wraps his h around it.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam! (he shakes the body) Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam! But Hodge has passed on, and Galen's magic has no way to reach him. Suddenly the youth cries out in pain. He drops the amulet and looks at his palm. The device has burned h flesh. Now he becomes aware of troubled Urlanders looking over his shoulder, witness to his failure.

dialogues.speaker: LAKE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Wind whips the leaden wave tops ona vast rainy lake. The travelers are rowing across in an open longboat, aided by tattered lateen sail. Valerian mans the steering oar at t stern while Galen broods in the bow. He feels like an imp in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FJORD
dialogues.text: The boat pulls into a long narrow waterway with granite c on either side. Moving through swirls of fog, they beach boat and step out onto a craggy shore. Greil leans over a kisses a rock.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Urland!

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: The travelers descend a mountain pass and emerge through wrack of cloud into a gray and cheerless region. Fire- blackened trees dot the barren landscape. As they reach t flatlands, the Urlanders instinctively pick up the pace. Galen slows to inspect the weird surroundings. Valerian t past him.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Come on. Don't dawdle here. Galen falls into step with her.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: The whole kingdom like this?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: No. We're near the lair. Keep moving. Galen looks around with new interest.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Over there. Doesn't matter. We're in no danger if we just pass through quickly. Galen stops. High on the slope beside them is a gaping fissure.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: I see it. Let's have a look.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: No! But Galen is already toiling up the incline.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Greil! Malkin! Help! The travelers turn to see what's the matter.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAIR
dialogues.text: Galen approaches the lair, pausing beside a wooden post w iron manacles dangling from it. He fingers them thoughtfu Malkin, Greil and Valerian rush up behind him, their face drawn with worry.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Look, you don't have to do this. We know you're a fine young magician. None better. There's no need to prove it to us.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Are there other entrances?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: No. One's enough.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Come on. The road's this way. We'll tell everybody how close you got.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (coolly) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  No smoke. How do you know it's in there?

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool. Come away now and live to tell about it. Instead, Galen starts into the crack. Greil and Malkin ha away, but Valerian lingers, watching in mounting frustrat as Galen probes further and further into the lair. She pi up a fistful of stones and throws them at him.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Go ahead! You're going to die! What a fine trick that will be! But Galen is lost in the gloom. She flees.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERGROUND
dialogues.text: Galen puts his hand on the rugged wall: the rocks are hot the touch. Something glinting on the floor catches Galen' eye: an irridescent disk, a dragon scale. lt flashes the colors of the rainbow as Galen examines it. All at once t ground shudders; chunks of rock fall from the ceiling. A pall of smoke billows up from the depths.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Galen staggers out of the fissure coughing and gagging in swirl of smoke. There is no sign of the Urlanders. He thr down his pack, climbs onto a huge boulder and surveys the massive cliffs rising behind the lair. He grasps the amul and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Now, great mountain, hear my command: Terrae lapsus consignet latibulum draconis! Evanescat latibulum draconis!

dialogues.speaker: LANDSLIDE
dialogues.text: With a thunderous splitting sound, the entire top of the cliff pitches forward and topples onto the lower half of Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca mountain, sweeping tons of debris into the air. Boulders size of houses bound down the mountain toward the magicia Eyes wide with awe, he turns and runs for his life. Even he careens down the slope, chunks of rock rumble past. On catches him at the knee and sends him flying. He covers his head and joins the landslide. Finally the d lifts and he finds himself in a gully face to face with t cowering Urlanders. They look with real fear at the man w just conjured up the Apocalypse. Tattered and torn, cover with dirt, Galen climbs up out of the shelter for a look his handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: The territory has been drastically transformed: the drago lair is now buried beneath hundreds of tons of broken gra The Urlanders look upon the new landscape with stupefacti Galen grins a triumphant splittip grin that fails to win them over. Presently they back away and run off down the trail, Valerian in their midst. Galen's grin fades.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGE
dialogues.text: The Village of Swanscombe is little more than a rough and ready collection of thatched huts and mud-daubed outbuild surrounded by cultivated fields. Dogs sleep in open door- ways; chickens peck around the communal well вЂ” but ther are no people in evidence as Valerian and her company tro into town.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: She trots across the square and enters a deserted blacksm shop.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Father? Hello? She goes over to the forge. Hot coals are burning. She be aware of a sound вЂ” voices вЂ” chanting.

dialogues.speaker: SQUARE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca She walks across the square toward the voices. She is jo by Greil, Malkin and the other travelers, all of them puz by the desolation. As they approach the grange hall the v grow louder. They seem to be singing. The main doors open briefly and three villagers scamper out, dripping wet and wrapped in white muslin. Valerian and her companions look each other in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GRANGE HALL
dialogues.text: In a wooden cistern in the middle of the hall a woman is being held under water. After a few moments she is pulled the surface by a tall red-haired man with long bony finge Brother Jacopus Januensis, a Carthusian monk. There's a w cross on his chest and a mad look in his eye. Gathered ar him are the missing villagers, every man woman and child, here to be baptised and sing a few newlytearned hymns in praise of Our Lord Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: Now are you cleansed of your sins! Now are you born again, purified in spirit, into the fellowship of Jesus Christ! The travelers enter and mingle with the congregation. Val scans the crowd until she locates her father, Simon, a ba sturdy journeyman. He's overjoyed at her return and gives her a hearty embrace.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Welcome back, my son.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Father, what are you doing? Have you all lost your minds?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Some have. He points to the monk, who is dunking a screaming infant carrying on about the Bishop of Rome.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  It's this monk. He can read and write, and talk too, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: And they listen?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Shh! They think this a holy place, a tabernacle.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: This is the granary. What kind of welcome is this? I've got news of the sorcerer and news of the dragon.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: You were brave to go, you and your friends. But nobody cares. Listen вЂ” he knows what they want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Brother Jacopus strides back and forth before the assembl in an inspired state.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: The man who walks with Christ is not a man to fear a dragon: Yea, though | walk through the valley of the shadow of death | will fear no evil! You say you are preyed upon by a foul beast. Yes, but what is the nature of this beast? It comes to you on bat's wings and clawed feet, does it not? It breathes fire, does it not? And it lives under ground. This is no dragon. This is Lucifer!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Whoever it is, he's dead. This is Galen, who has just stepped into the hall, tatter bedraggled and triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Nay, brother! It is not as easy as that. Allegiance to Christ, to be sure, but also prayer and confession. These are the arms by which Satan may be put down.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: You're talking about superstition, friend. None of that has anything to do with what I, Galen, have already achieved. He marches to the center of the gathering.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (to Valerian) You brought this stranger?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Ulrich's apprentice. He's a braggart, but it doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: People of Urland! Send a messenger to the king. Vermithrax is dead. Crushed by the power of the moon and the stars! Laid low by ancient wisdom. Dropped into the Abyss by mystical practice.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: Spoken like a pagan. Every word as reprobate as it is false! (holding up his cross) Solum in hoc signo vinces!

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Nihil plus mysterium! He gestures boldly and a fireball crackles at the monk's feet. The holy man scurries back. A hush falls upon the congregation.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A procession of curious villagers winds its way into the badlands. They gather on a promontory overlooking the dra lair. They stand there for a long time, a chill wind whip their garments, trying to understand what's happened. The monk is mightily displeased.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: Praise God! Blessed is he that is humble before the Lord!

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Your god had nothing to do with it. Indeed, Galen's act is already the stuff of legend:

dialogues.speaker: MALKIN
dialogues.text: We saw it with our own eyes. He flew to the mountain top. He was a bird. He brought forth lightning. | saw it. Some of the younger villagers scamper forward to the spot where the cave had its opening. With yells and whoops the beat the ground with clubs. In the crowd Simon begins to smile, then to laugh. Soon he leads the villagers in a tumultuous cheer. Brother Jacopus and some of his convert drop to their knees and pray.

dialogues.speaker: CELEBRATION
dialogues.text: The inhabitants of Swanscombe have decked out the town sq and are making a night of it. By torchlight they dance me to jigs and reels provided by the local fiddlers. Ale flo freely from oak casks.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Valerian is kneeling before a trunk full of women's cloth She pulls out a long simple frock, goes to a crude mirror and holds it up against her body to gauge the effect. Her father comes up behind her. He is angry and frightened. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put that away. What if you were seen?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: I'm going to be seen. | want to be seen. Tonight the world finds out that you never had a son.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: No, you mustn't do that. It's too soon. We've got to think about this, we've got to make a plan.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Father: the danger is over. He sits on the bed and puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: | know. What am I going to say to my friends who still mourn for their lost girls.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: You'll say you did what you had to. This is a time for celebration вЂ” and forgiveness. He looks up at her, trying to imagine what it's going to like having a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CELEBRATION
dialogues.text: Galen is surrounded by a crowd of wide-eyed kids and nota few adults, entertaining them by pulling duck's eggs out their ears and causing coins to disappear. Presently he f the attention of his audience shift away to someone stand behind him. He turns to find a shy but determined Valeria sweetly decked out in her blue frock. A buzz goes through the crowd. Valerian blushes and wavers: she seems ready t bolt for home. But Galen takes her by the hand, and with conspicuous politesse leads her to the dance.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca It's forward, back and around sixth-century style: the y sorcerer can't take his eyes off his partner. But she's t shy to return his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Looks like you've been up to a little sorcery yourself. Valerian doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Or is it witchcraft? She still doesn't reply. It's all she can do to keep on dancing.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: What's the matter? A real woman never stops talking.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: | think it was much easier being a boy.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: They stand on the sidelines, watching the young couple st to the music.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: The damnedest thing is, she was twice the man of anyone else in the village. Now she's twice the woman.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: (grim) Would that | had been as clever as her father.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Come now, Greil. Don't begrudge a life spared.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  | begrudge nothing. But | wonder at what we have seen and how it was done.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: You were there.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: | saw what | saw. But this jack-anapes was barely ready to carry his master's chamberpot. Isn't it strange that at the very moment the beast is put down we should have a holy man here in the village?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: You don't believe that superstitious Christian rot, do you?

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: (defensive) It is said God works his wonders in mysterious ways.

dialogues.speaker: CELEBRATION
dialogues.text: While the proud Simon dances in the background with his daughter, a group of tipsy villagers clusters around Gale belching forth a drinking song. The young magician raises his own mug and joins in on the chorus. Abruptly the musi stops. The singing dies away. The ensuing silence is brok by the sound of galloping hooves. Presently three horseme appear at the end of town: Tyrian and his henchmen. They guide their horses forward into the midst of the merry-ma Tyrian dismounts and looks around in his usual friendly w

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: A celebration! Don't stop on my account. You вЂ” musicians, more music! The musicians leave their instruments in their laps. Tyri draws himself a measure of ale and raises it above his he

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: A toast! To the deed of the day! You Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  see, good news travels fast. The King himself has already heard it. And like yourselves, tonight he's overcome with joy.

dialogues.speaker: MALKIN
dialogues.text: What would you have of us then?

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Not a thing. It's this one. (he gestures toward Galen) The King would meet our new benefactor and offer his gratitude to the man who succeeded where so many have failed.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (sobering up) What sort of gratitude? A knife in the belly? An arrow in the back? Tyrian's smile freezes on his face. He steps in front of Galen, towering over him.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: My young friend, I'd as soon dispatch you as | did the others, and for the same reason. But his Majesty would like a cozy chat, and commands otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Don't go, Galen. Cast a spell and turn them into toads. It should be easy; that's what they are. Tyrian regards her coolly, taking in her change of costum and its meaning.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Well, well: still plenty of cheek under those skirts, it seems. Having buried the dragon under a mountain, Galen decides Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca he's not worried about an appearance at court. He smiles Valerian.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: RIDERS
dialogues.text: Three horses gallop through the moors and fens of central Urland. Galen is tucked up behind Tyrian. On the distant horizon, the battlements of the King's castle glow in the slanting light of a new day.

dialogues.speaker: THRONE ROOM
dialogues.text: Within the castle is a great hall with shafts of daylight poking in through narrow windows set high in the walls. I the middle of the room stands a carved oak throne. There Casiodorus Rex, King of Urland, a bearded man in his fift as spare and somber as the room in which he sits. He is flanked by a few servants, assorted courtiers and Tyrian. Standing before them all is Galen, looking unhappy. He po a pitcher full of water into a small glazed goblet.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: One of the best things about the water here in Urland is that there's so much of it вЂ” look at that! Water continues to pour into the goblet without overflowi Galen takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Mmm. Good. But not cold enough. Perhaps | could borrow a scarf from his Majesty. The King makes no sign. Galen approaches stiffly, takes a scarf and retreats.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  I cover the goblet, so... remove, so...and behold: winter in a mug! And he's done it: he turns the goblet over and a small ch of ice hits the floor. The royal reaction is equally fros Galen is bombing, and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: All right. How many of you have ever seen a table fly? He mutters an incantation. In the audience, Tyrian notes that Galen has his hand wrapped around the amulet. There a loud clatter as the heavy oak table before the throne b to jitter and buck. As the wine spills and plates go flyi the King wearily raises a hand.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Enough! That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Wait, it'll rise now.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Don't bother. Not necessary. The table cracks in half and dumps a mess of fruit and crockery at the onlookers' feet.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Tell me: the landslide вЂ” it was accomplished this same way?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: I see. And having rendered such unique service to our kingdom, what would you claim as a reward?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Please вЂ”no payment. | have always found magical practice to be its own reward. | seek only some yet greater Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  challenge. This handsome sentiment doesn't go over any better than h tricks.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Did you ever hear of King Gaiseric? Of course not, you weren't even born. He was my brother, a great King and a valiant man-at-arms. When he ascended to the throne, the dragon was unbridled. No one knew where it might strike next. So he brought forth his broadsword and his spear, assembled a company of his best fighters and went out to do battle. (pause) He was never seen again. But his attack provoked the most terrible reprisals: whole villages incinerated, entire crops burned. Death, famine, horrible. The King grimaces as the memories come flooding back.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: (quietly) How did you arrogate to yourself the role of savior?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: | was invited.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Not by me. Did you ever consider the consequences of failure?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: What failure? What's the matter with you people? You want the dragon back?

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Then the beast is dead?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Yes, of course. Dead.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: We shall see.

dialogues.speaker: DUNGEON
dialogues.text: Two guards thrust Galen into a narrow cell and slam the b door shut. The young sorcerer waits until they're safely of sight, then takes out his amulet. He ponders it for a doubtful moment. Suddenly a gloved hand darts in and whip it off his neck and out through the bars.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. He makes an ironic salute and leaves. Galen sits down hea and stares at the stone walls.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Unseen by Galen, a figure clad in silk and lace skitters down a murky dungeon hallway and peers around a corner. Stealing a look at Galen is the Princess Elspeth, a fey b in her early twenties. After a moment, spooked by some imagined noise, she flits away.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: Dark clouds slide across a pale sun, throwing the ruined land below into shadow. Soon fat droplets of rain are splattering on the rocks above the dragon's lair. With ea tiny splash there is a sizzle and a puff of steam. These rocks are hot!

dialogues.speaker: DUNGEON
dialogues.text: Outside the barred window, a steady rain is falling. Insi Galen uses a chunk of limestone to inscribe a pentagram o Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca the floor of his cell. He marks runic signs on the windo sill and lintel. Then, positioning himself in the center the mystic symbol, he raises his hands and spreads his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (authoritative) Cubiculum gravis aperat! There's a long moment when nothing happens. A very long moment. Finally, a thoroughly frustrated Galen leaps to t window and rattles the bars.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Open up, dammit! Fenestra gravis aperat! Asser gravis aperat! Divinitus!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Salve, magistrum iuvenilum. Startled, Galen whirls around to find Elspeth standing ou his cell. She hands some food and blankets through the ba

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: I've studied Latin. Greek, too. Me appelo Elspeth, filia regis. Galen looks her over. He's never seen anyone so angelic.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Please don't think ill of us. My father is a wonderful man, a wise man. The lottery was his idea.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Isee.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: You don't understand. From the moment it began, the dragon was tame. The kingdom prospered. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And only a few had to be sacrificed.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Yes, that's true. Isn't it better that a few should die that many might live?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Depends on who does the dying.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Oh, but we all take our chances. My father is a just man. My name is entered on the lists, along with every other young вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Virgin?

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Maiden.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: (sighs) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: I've participated in every drawing since | came of age.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: It's true. You don't believe me. You think I'm lying. Well I'm not. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. | heard a rumor. Families with money, that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Don't listen to rumors. They're lies. Ihave to go now.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Wait вЂ” how long do I have to stay in here?

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Until we know. Not long. Goodbye. Vale. Dormi bene. She slips away down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARY
dialogues.text: King Casiodorus and Tyrian are huddled over a table piled high with manuscripts and papers. Tyrian clears a spot an sets out a stack of lead bars.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: That's enough. Let's not be greedy here. The King picks up Galen's amulet, and holds it over the b in his clenched fist.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Now then: |, Casiodorus Rex do hereby command thou base metal to change thy essence and become gold. There is a rustle of skirts and Elspeth appears behind hi

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Father?

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Not now. Tyrian, remove all but one bar. We'll try it one at a time. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father: did you know that some families have paid bribes to stay out of the lottery? The King and Tyrian glance up at her.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Nonsense. By the power of this amulet, justly wielded by my hand in accordance with the laws of Urland, now lead be thou gold. The lead remains unchanged, but the King gives out a cry drops the amulet.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: I'm burned! What devilish thing is this?

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Have you ever kept my name off the lottery list?

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: That'll be all, Tyrian. You may withdraw. Tyrian bows and exits. The King uses his sceptre to pick the amulet and chain. He conceals it in a hollowed-out bo and places the volume on a shelf among many others.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Now, my dear, what's troubling you?

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Answer my question: am | not exposed to the same risk as every other man's daughter? The King paces over to the window and stares out. The rai has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: Well? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Your father loves you very much. Elspeth sways in dismay.

dialogues.speaker: ELSPETH
dialogues.text: (a wail) It's true! What have you done to me!?

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Who fills your head with such ideas? At that moment a tremor passes through the room. King and daughter look at each other in alarm.

dialogues.speaker: DUNGEON
dialogues.text: The same tremor shakes the bars in Galen's cell. Puzzled, rolls off his straw palette and gets to his feet. The tre dies away. Suddenly a violent shaking hits the cell, boun Galen off the walls.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGE SQUARE
dialogues.text: Swanscombe is gripped by the same earthquake. Dodging pan barnyard animals, Valerian and her father join other frightened villagers in the center of town.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: Above the dragon's lair, boulders are shifting and grindi together. Massive chunks of stone break loose and tumble down the incline.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  The shaking has stopped. Rock dust filters down from the ceiling. Galen picks himself up and stares: the door to h cell is off its hinges and is sagging open. He darts out.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Galen dashes along the hallway, rounds a corner and stops At the other end of the passage is Tyrian.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: You little meddler! It's alive! He draws his sword and advances. Galen warily retreats. T breaks into a run. Galen turns and sprints away.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Unruly horses, terrified by the quake, rush blindly aroun the courtyard. Hostlers try vainly to catch them. Tyrian leans down from an upstairs window.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Close the main gate! Quick! The men below scramble for the gates. Galen bursts out of hiding, sees the untended horses, and swings aboard as on goes past. A cry goes up from the guards.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: There! Stop him! Galen rides like mad for the exit, but he's a half-second late: the doors boom shut in his face. He wheels the hors around. The King's men are coming toward him with pikes. Digging his heels into the horse's sides, he urges the an back across the courtyard, up the steps and right into th building!

dialogues.speaker: THRONE ROOM
dialogues.text: Galen gallops into the empty chamber, knocking over the t and vaulting a table. Hot on his heels are armed soldiers He kicks the horse again and shoots under an archway.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  The kitchen is already in chaos from the earthquake when Galen charges in on his wild steed. Food, utensils and co go flying. He reins in, ducks his head, and squeezes the horse out into a narrow hallway.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: He clatters down the passageway. But here comes a conting of footmen from the opposite direction. Galen rides them into the walls!

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS
dialogues.text: The horse scrabbles up the stairs, Galen tucked low again its neck. On the upper landing he comes face to face with Tyrian and more soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: TYRIAN
dialogues.text: Get him! Stab the horse! Galen jerks the animal around and plunges back down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Whinnying and blowing the horse bursts in, a wild-eyed Ga still in the saddle. He finds himself confronting the Kin and his daughter. Casiodorus grabs Elspeth and retreats into a corner.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: Tyrian! Tyrian! Tyrian sweeps in with his men. The doors slam shut.

dialogues.speaker: KING
dialogues.text: So much for your magic! So much for your sorcery! Galen is trapped. Just as Tyrian reaches for the horse's reins, the animal rears up, rolling its eyes. At that mom the floor heaves and cracks in a new series of shocks. Th men at arms go down like ten pins. Tyrian reels back, dod Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  stone blocks loosened from the ceiling. As the shaking continues, a weakened section of wall gives way. Galen se daylight! Without even waiting for the quake to cease, he prods the horse across the room and through the wall to freedom.

dialogues.speaker: DRAGON COUNTRY
dialogues.text: The unnerved citizens of Swanscombe gather on the promont overlooking Galen's landslide. Every few seconds there is new shudder and more rocks pour down the long slope. Vale stands trembling with her father. Presently Brother Jacop elbows his way forward.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: Listen to me, my brethren. The moment of our fear is the moment of our triumph. This is a sign from God. Follow me, and our faith will send this creature straight to hell. Holding a cross before him, he starts up the slope. No on follows. They haven't been Christians all that long. One two near Valerian get down on their knees and pray silent Greil looks things over.

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: You call yourselves Christians? He strides after the monk. But he's the only one.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE LAIR
dialogues.text: The determined monk has arrived at the epicenter. His san are smoking on the hot gravel. Sweat shines on his face a neck.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: The Lord is my shepherd, | shall not want. Thou makest me to lie down in green pastures. Thy rod and staff they comfort me... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Greil toils up the slope a hundred yards back. He's cros himself, but he's carrying a sickle.

dialogues.speaker: VERMITHRAX
dialogues.text: There is a thunderous noise. Part of the mountain is toss into the air. Up from the depths comes a huge shining win Then a neck uncoils and a head appears. It tips down towa the tiny human.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: (firm) ..for Thine is the kingdom and the power and the glory forever вЂ” amen. At the base of the slope the villagers scatter. Greil wav

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER JACOPUS
dialogues.text: Unclean beast, get thee down! Be thou consumed by the fires that made you! The dragon's head sways back and forth, then belches out waterfall of flame. It engulfs Jacopus and sends him to a better world, if there is one.

dialogues.speaker: HILL ROAD
dialogues.text: Horse and rider race across a night landscape under brood clouds. Up ahead, the sky glows with an angry red light. the crest of a hill Galen reins in and looks down across long valley. There, miles away, is the village of Swansco Many buildings are ablaze. As he watches in horror, fires spring up in the fields and trees. Intermittently he can the silhouette of the dragon as it spreads destruction. Finally the creature swoops up and away. Galen stares sky losing sight of it in the clouds. For a moment, silence. Then, with a thunderous rush of air that almost blows him from the saddle, the dragon reappears and hurtles a few f over his head! It is gone in an instant.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the buildings in the town are on fire. Desperate villagers dash here and there, herding children and anima to safety, trying to save their household goods. Galen wa woodenly into the confusion, leading his horse, taking in the scope of the disaster. He comes upon a line of men wh have formed a bucket brigade. He attempts to join up. As soon as he is recognized, he is shouldered roughly aside.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Get away, you little bastard. We've had enough help from you. Galen staggers back, reaching for his horse. The animal s and trots off. A middle-aged woman appears in front of hi her face contorted with rage. She swings a flaming broom catches him on the back of the head. Galen reels away.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: This is your doing! Galen looks up and sees a couple of burlies moving his wa with boards in their hands.

dialogues.speaker: BURLIES
dialogues.text: Get him! He's back! Before they can get too close, Galen runs down an alley a bumps smack into a glassy-eyed, haunted man. It is Greil.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Greil вЂ” help!

dialogues.speaker: GREIL
dialogues.text: May the Lord forgive you for what you have done. He pushes past. Galen ducks behind a smoldering building.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The roof has burned off, but at least the walls are stand Valerian is wrestling charred timbers out of the center o the room. She is covered with soot. There is a hammering Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca the door and Galen barges in. He slams the door behind h and puts his back against it.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: It's me. Are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Doesn't matter вЂ” listen: Quick! Make it rain. That'll put the fire out.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: Then get the animals back. They're all running loose. There's people been hurt. Stop their pain. You can cure them. And we'll need food...

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Ican't do it.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
dialogues.text: (this stops her) What? Why not? Galen's hand moves up to where the amulet used to hang.

dialogues.speaker: GALEN
dialogues.text: Ijust can't.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIAN
